As a district, we have been planning for re-entry over the past several months. Careful consideration has been given to preparing an environment where all students feel excited to learn. As a staff, we miss each of the students and can’t wait to serve them in person or virtually very soon.

After examining the recommendations presented by the St. Francois County Health Department, the North County School Board and administrative team have made the decision to delay the start of school for all students until September 8, 2020.

Pushing back the start date will provide a better opportunity to slow the spread of COVID-19 within our community. When we return on September 8, we will open school in the Yellow Phase of our Re-Entry Plan. The district will require masks for all students and staff during this phase as an additional measure to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. Thank you for your understanding as we continue to prepare for serving students.

Sincerely-

Dr. Jeff Levy and the North County Board of Education

Tracy is proud to be a North County parent and teacher!

Registered voters within the North St. Francois County School District are being asked to consider a $13.5 million no tax increase bond issue on Tuesday, June 2.

Prop S is our district's continued commitment to providing a safe and secure environment for all students and staff. Projects within this bond issue include secure vestibules for all buildings, updated security cameras throughout the district, increased ADA accessibility, HVAC updates, and many other projects.

For more information, please review https://www.ncsd.k12.mo.us/?page_id=1771.

We encourage our community to vote on Tuesday, June 2, 2020.

Last week, 3rd grade students learned about empathy. Each student was asked to write about what life is like through their eyes. They then got the opportunity to better understand classmates by reading everyone’s “Through my eyes...” paper.

The students were asked to write one thing holding them back on the trees for the “fixed mindset forest.” They were also asked to write one positive thing on the stars to help move away from their fixed mindset to a growth mindset.

post_text: Students in Mrs. Thomas's and Mr. Pasternak's science classes participated in the Ameren Missouri Energy Efficiency Program. The program is funded through a grant with Ameren and Spire. Students studied the advantages and disadvantages of using renewable and non renewable resources. Each student received an energy efficient kit that includes LED light bulbs, faucet aerators, an energy efficient shower head, thermal insulation wrap, and tools for collecting data. Students were also supplied with a take home book full of experiments. Families are educated on ways to conserve water and energy. Both classroom teachers will be able to earn $50 to spend on classroom supplies after completion of the program.

Mr. Casey Hovis visited North County Intermediate science classes on Monday, November 11th. Casey and his sister, Kassie Hovis Black (our Intermediate School nurse), were both students in Mrs. Thomas's 6th grade math/science class. Casey graduated in 2008 from North County High School, spent five years in the Marines, and has since been working for the FAA at Kansas City International Airport. Casey spoke to the classes about his experiences flying and on his career. He discussed the importance of doing your best in all subjects and several topics that our students have learned in their math and science classes, including altitude, barometric pressure, air density, Newton's laws of motion, unit conversions, math formulas, and variables such as how wind affects the speed of the airplane. He also explained to the classes the different avenues to working in air traffic control.

Thank you, Casey, for your service to our country and for taking time on Veteran's day to come and speak to our students!
